posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
I have a simple arm that needs to move 90 degree. It’s 24 lbm overall weight, its CG is about 12" from the pivot. I need to move it about 2 seconds from 0 horizontal to 90 degree. Arm needs to stay at 90 degree for about 40 seconds, before it need to go back down.

Packaging is important, so the smaller the motor + gear box, the better (especially the motor size).

I’m using this JVN Calc, which helps alot to go thru iteration. Planning to use 2 gearboxed motors, one on each side of the arm.  I don’t know what the Gearbox efficiency number is for each size, but I’m assuming the planetary gearbox is not the same albeit the this affect the angular speed minimally. I used 65% eff for all.

I’m looking at 2 outputs from these iterations, the current draw and rotation speed.

with the NEO 550 I have: NEO550 538×514 52.5 KB NEO V1.1: NEO V1.1 548×522 52 KB Falcon 500 Falcon 500 552×513 52.6 KB

NEO550 538×514 52.5 KB

NEO550 538×514 52.5 KB

NEO V1.1 548×522 52 KB

NEO V1.1 548×522 52 KB

Falcon 500 552×513 52.6 KB

Falcon 500 552×513 52.6 KB

From this calc, it seems like NEO 550 is the best candidate. Current draw is under 20A and has the best rotational speed.

I could probably get away with one motor gearboxed looking at this calculation too since it is well below 20A current limit.

Thoughts?

posts.name: Frank Lima
posts.cooked:
You are holding the gearbox constant instead of holding the final output RPM and Torque as constant.

Each motor will have different optimal gear ratio. When optimizing your setup your motors “working” RPM should be 70% to 80% of the motors free speed for ideal performance.

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
Yes, with bigger motor, I could get away with less reduction. I was also comparing the overall package of geared motor 60:1 NEO550 vs 5:1 Falcon/NEO. NEO550 was still much smaller and shorter.

Are you saying that 70-80% of the Free Speed is what i should use for the calculating final output RPM ?

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: In my personal experience, neo 550s don’t like being held at 20a during stall. We’ve burnt too many. According to the constant current test from motors.vex.com (note, tests from VEX, not from REV), a neo 550 survives at 20a, but that hasn’t been my personal experience. I’d try to avoid stalling them at more than 10a-15a if you can avoid it. https://motors.vex.com/media/wysiwyg/ConstantCurrent_2.PNG

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked: If you do 60:1 on a NEO550, don’t use the ultraplanetary.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Frank Lima
posts.cooked:
MSU2000:

Are you saying that 70-80% of the Free Speed is what i should use for the calculating final output RPM ?

Correct, ~70% of free speed * Gear ratio * efficiency loss = final working RPM

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
